newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China says plans to cut fiscal deficit.
newsitem.headline: China says plans to cut fiscal deficit.

text.p: Chinese Finance Minister Liu Zhongli said China had mapped out a plan to gradally cut its fiscal deficit, the South China Morning said on Sunday.
Liu, in comments reported in the South China Morning Post, said the Chinese government aimed to keep the deficit at no more than three percent of the budget.

"Our total deficit should not exceed three percent of the budget," the Post quoted Liu as saying. The paper said his remarks were an edited version of an interview that will appear in the Germany daily Handelsblatt.
"It currently floats around three percent and we are working hard to lower this figure," he said.
Liu said China expects to cut its deficit by eight percent this year to 61.4 billion yuan from 66.2 billion last year.
"By the year 2000, we want to cut the deficit by 10 to 20 billion yuan," he said.
"Of course this doesn't solve the problem as we have an accumulated debt burden from past years and this includes not only the servicing of the principal but also the interest."
Asked whether China would venture into international bond markets in the future, the finance minister said China would not be very active.
"We don't need to be very active on the international bond markets as we can make use of the investment money and the savings here," he said.
"To the question as to which markets we prefer we look at Hong Kong, Tokyo, London and Germany and take into consideration the currency, the interest rates and the issuing costs," he added.
Liu also said investment had not faltered after the central government abolished tax privileges for joint venture companies.
"We have conducted a survey. Major international players thought it was only natural for a country to do this," he said.
"They really don't care about adjustments of customs duties and the reduction of duties for imported capital goods. They care about the markets."
Liu said planners were also struggling with the issue of reforming state-owned companies, many of which are vastly overstaffed and losing money.
"We have to smash the iron rice pot," he said, in a reference to the welfare for life programme that is offered by Chinese state companies.
Massive payouts for employee welfare are hobbling many state firms as they try to modernise in the wake of economic reforms and an influx of leaner, better-funded foreign competitors.
While private western companies often respond to bloated debt or spending by cutting staff, that option is politically sensitive for Chinese firms run by the state.
"They (state enterprises) must be told that if they fail in the long term they will go bankrupt," Liu said.

"But before we have a social security in place it is difficult. That's the reason we hesitate to really reform the state-owned enterprises. Only if we have the social security system in place can we separate government and business."

When asked what was his biggest headache aside from the sick state sector, Liu replied: "Too many people ask me for favours and money. They want a faster, quicker development and civil servants want bigger salaries like in all the other countries.
"It won't be easy."
